message: Relatively new to Django. I'm integrating an iOS client with a Django API. The big HTML debug page is great if you're using it a browser but it's a huge pain otherwise. Is there a better way to set up Django if you're using it in this manner?
the decorator i use is like this: https://github.com/markpasc/make-a-face/blob/master/makeaface/makeaface/views.py#L32
@amrox For API views that return machine responses, I usually use a decorator that catches exceptions and turns them into plaintext or JSON error responses
Turn debug mode off in settings and you'll get tracebacks by e-mail. This is what you'll have to do once in production anyway. Django-sentry lets you view tracebacks with a browser, too.
yeah, for actually getting the error out, use sentry. it gives you a page like the admin that you can sign into that errors can be logged to.
the sentry page will have all the traceback info that's in the nice debug page, but with debug off the client will get your regular 500 page
i still use the decorator approach so even the 500s for API views are still delivered in XML or JSON or whatever

as indicated in : http://stackoverflow.com/questions/164427/change-django-templates-based-on-user-agent the details of process_response are in: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.3/topics/http/middleware/#process_response
as others have mentioned, your API should be flexible enough (using middleware) to return a cleanly-formatted JSON response with an error code / message
You can also create  a MobileMiddleware to check if the request is mobile (request.mobile) as indicated in:and alter the response with a process_response
but use something like e-mail or Sentry to actually debug it yourself
